definition:
If $Th$ and $Pr$ are two sets of facts (in particular, a theory of some
language and the set of things provable by some method) we say $Pr$ is
*sound* for $Th$ if $Pr\subseteq Th$. Typically we have a theory and set
of rules for constructing proofs, and we say the set of rules are sound
(which theory is intended is usually clear from context) since
everything they prove is true (in $Th$).

If $Th\subseteq Pr$ we say $Pr$ is *complete* for $Th$. Again, we
usually have a theory and a set of rules for constructing proofs, and
say that the set of rules is complete since everything true (in $Th$)
can be proven.
